As those natives who have more resources leave, those left behind may struggle to support churches, police athletic leagues, parent-teacher associations, and local businesses. State and local policymakers are understandably focused on the economic consequences of brain drain.

Brain drain has significant consequences‚Äîeconomic, yes, but also political and cultural. It limits opportunities for disparate groups to connect. By siphoning a source of economic innovation from emptying communities, it can also lead to crumbling institutions of civil society.
On the other hand, states in the Southeast, in the Rust Belt, and in other parts of the country tend to fare much worse when it comes to retaining and attracting the highly-educated.

Our research finds that states that are doing the best‚Äîlow gross brain drain and net brain gain‚Äîgenerally cluster along the Boston-Washington corridor and on the West Coast: #Massachusetts, #NewYork, #NewJersey, #Maryland, #California, #Oregon, and #Washington.

The outmigration of highly-educated adults has almost certainly played a role in the deterioration of civil society in struggling communities across the country. It has likely exacerbated distrust of people who hold different beliefs.

Brain Drain: States that retain & attract highly-educated adults stand to reap substantial economic benefits.
